Editor’s choice paper Metal-salen-bridged ionic networks as efficient bifunctional solid catalysts for chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates Chenjun Zhang Dan Lu Yan Leng ⁎ Pingping Jiang The Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids, Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Material Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, China The Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Biological Colloids Ministry of Education School of Chemical Material Engineering Jiangnan University Wuxi 214122 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Novel metal-Salen-bridged ionic polymer Networks were demonstrated to be highly efficient bifunctional catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 and Epoxides, presenting high activity and steady reuse. A series of bifunctional heterogeneous ionic polymer networks M-Salen-TBB-R were developed by reacting archetype of metal-salophen wtih 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(bromomethyl)benzene, followed by treatment with ionic liquid groups. Various techniques such as 1H NMR, TGA, CHN elemental analysis, SEM, FT-IR, XPS, and ICP-AES were used to characterize these catalysts. A number of attractive features like highly cross-linked polymer framework, abundant active sites of Lewis acid metal centers and nucleophile Br−, and various N-containing functional cations that endow the resultant catalysts with an expected talent for fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) under mild and solvent-cocatalyst-free conditions. The catalytic tests by comparison to various synthesized counterparts well demonstrate that this catalyst exhibit excellent activity and selectivity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, and the catalyst can be conveniently recovered and reused. The durable cross-linked network structure of catalyst and the cooperative effect between the metal center, Br−, and organic cations are responsible for the catalyst’s good performances in cycloaddition reactions. Keywords Carbon dioxide Cycloaddition Bifunctional catalysts Ionic polymers Metal-salen complexes 1 Introduction Due to environmental concerns caused by the massive emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) [1,2], the physical adsorption and chemical fixation of CO2 have become very important and popular subjects. CO2 can be chemically fixed to organic compounds by reaction with various coupling partners. For example, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates is highly desirable. This is an efficient resource utilization and 100% atom economic process, and the CO2 cycloaddition products [3,4], cyclic carbonates, have been widely used as aprotic solvents, electrolytes in lithium-ion secondary batteries, intermediates of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals [5,6]. Various homogeneous catalysts like quaternary alkyl ammonium [7–9], phosphonium salts [10], ionic liquids [11,12] and transition metal complexes [13], have been used for the production of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides, but catalyst separation and disposal present both environmental and economic drawbacks. Meanwhile, many types of heterogeneous catalysts, including metal oxides [14], metalloporphyrins [15–17], ionic organic polymers [18], and metal-organic frameworks [19] have also been explored to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2. However, those catalytic reactions are usually performed at high temperatures (>100°C) and/or under high CO2 pressures (>30atm) owing to the thermodynamic stability of CO2. Moreover, additives and/or cocatalysts like potassium bromide and cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide, as well as organic solvents are usually needed in most of these cases. Therefore, to explore high efficiency recyclable catalysts for the coupling reactions of epoxides with CO2 under mild conditions is still essential. Recently, metal-organic polymerization materials are very attractive because of their readily availability and highly tailorability of metal and organic ligand for multifunctional integration [20,21]. Further, metal-organic polymerization materials with high density of catalytically active units on the polymer framework can be used as heterogeneous catalysts. In this context, several groups have successfully developed effective metal-organic polymerization catalysts using metal-Salen species as building blocks for the chemical fixation of CO2 [22,23]. For example, Bhaumik et al. synthesized zinc-Salen functionalized porous polymer, which exhibited good catalytic performance for the cycloaddition reaction [24]. Kureshy et al. prepared a number of polyether-based polymeric Co(III) Salen complexes and applied them as highly efficient cycloaddition catalysts, and the solid catalysts can be steadily reused [25]. Nevertheless, these catalytic processes still require the presence of co-catalysts such as Bu4NBr (TBAB). On the other hand, many researches have demonstrated that the introduction of Lewis acid metal center and nucleophile X− in one catalyst can cause cooperative effects, which is beneficial for the coupling reaction of CO2 and epoxides under cocatalyst-free conditions [15,26,27]. Very recently, we have prepared a bifunctional solid catalyst by grafting Salen-Co Schiff base on the surface of ionic polymer microspheres [28]. Although it showed good performance in the cycloaddition of CO2, the core-shell structure of the catalyst is actually unsatisfactory because it not only limit the loading amount of Salen-Co species but also impede the Br− anions in the bulk phase of catalyst microspheres giving full play as active centres. Encouraged by the highly tailorability and high density of active units of metal-organic polymers and the excellent activity of Lewis acid/nucleophile X− bifunctional catalyst, in this work, we developed a new strategy for combining metal-Salen complexes with halogen anion together to form metal-Salen-bridged ionic polymer networks for synthesis of cyclic carbonates under mild and cocatalyst-free conditions. A cross-linked network involving a stable metal-Salen compound as the building unit was prepared by reacting archetype of metal-salophen wtih 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(bromomethyl)benzene (TBB). Then, appended ionic liquid substituents were introduced into the skeleton of polymer networks, resulting in dual catalytically active centers in one catalyst. The resulting catalyst displayed durable structure associated with abundant metal center and anion Br−. Systematic catalytic tests for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides demonstrate that coordination-induced activation of epoxides by metal-Salen species and Br− anions resulted in the enhancement in catalytic efficiency even at 0.5MPa and a temperature of 80°C. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and method The detailed materials and method are shown in Supporting information (SI). 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of salen ligand Salen ligand was prepared following the literature [29] with slight modification. Briefly, 4-(Diethylamino)salicylaldehyde (30mmol, 5.80g) in methanol (50mL) was added slowly to a solution of 3,3′-Diaminobenzidine (5mmol, 1.29g) in hot methanol (200mL). After stirring for 24h at 90°C, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, the yellow solid product was collected by vacuum filtration and washed with cold methanol for several times, then dried at 60°C for 12h to give the Salen ligand (yield: 84.3%). H1 NMR (400MHz, CDCl3, TMS) δ(ppm)=1.21 (t, 24H, CH3), 3.41 (m, 16H, CH2), 6.23 (t, 8H, CH), 7.17 (m, 4H, CH), 7.28(d, 2H, CH), 7.44 (t, 4H, CH), 8.47 (s,2H, CH), 8.53 (s, 2H, CH), 13.74 (s, 4H, OH). (Fig. S1, SI). CHN elemental analysis results: calcd (wt%): C 73.49%, H 7.27%, N 12.24%; found: C 73.72%, H 7.36%, N 12.44%. 2.2.2 Synthesis of ionic polymer networks M-Salen-TBB M-Salen-TBB was prepared according to the literature [24]. The obtained Salen ligand (1mmol, 0.92g) was dissolved in trichloromethane (10mL), and 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(bromomethyl)benzene (TBB, 2mmol, 0.90g) was dissolved in toluene (20mL). Then the above two solutions were mixed, and the 10mL methanol solution of Co(OAc)2·4H2O (2.2mmol, 0.55g) was added into the mixture. After stirring at room temperature for 15min, the mixture was transferred into an autoclave at 100°C for 24h. The dull-red solid product was filtered out and washed with trichloromethane for three times. After drying at 50°C for 12h, the product Co-Salen bridged ionic polymer network was obtained (yield: 52%), named as Co-Salen-TBB. Zn-Salen-TBB and Al-Salen-TBB were prepared with a similar preparation process using zinc acetate dihydrate and diethylaluminum chloride as metal sources, respectively. Zn-Salen-TBB and Al-Salen-TBB were finally obtained as brown and khaki solid powders with 45% and 67% yield, respectively. Metal-free ionic polymer Salen-TBB was prepared in the same way without adding Co(OAc)2·4H2O. 2.2.3 Synthesis of M-Salen-TBB-R The obtained Co-Salen-TBB was further modified with different IL groups, such as pyridine (Py), imidazole (Mim), triethylamine (TEA), or triethanolamine (TEOA). For example, Co-Salen-TBB (1.0g) was dispersed in 10mL toluene, then, Py (0.32g) was added dropwise, and the mixture was refluxed for 24h. On completion, the resulting solid product Co-Salen-TBB-Py was collected by filtration and washing with ethanol for several times, followed by drying in a vacuum for 24h at 50°C. The Co content in Co-Salen-TBB-Py 4.71wt% was determined by ICP-AES, and CHN elemental analysis of fresh Co-Salen-TBB-Py (C 49.75wt%, H 5.24wt%,N 5.86wt%) was detected. Co-Salen-TBB-TEOA, Co-Salen-TBB-TEA, Co-Salen-TBB-Mim, Zn-Salen-TBB-Py, and Al-Salen-TBB-Py were prepared accordingly. FT-IR and TG characterizations for these catalysts are shown in Figs. S2 and S3 in SI. 2.3 General procedure for the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 In a 50mL stainless-steel autoclave, catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py (0.05g) and propylene oxide (PO) (20.66mmol) were added into it. 0.5MPa CO2 was then charged into the reactor. After reacting at 80°C for 8h, the resulting mixture was centrifuged. The liquid was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (SP-6890A, FID, DB-wax capillary column) using biphenyl as an internal standard. GC–MS (SCIONSQ-456-GC) was also used to confirm the purity and structure of the products. The recovered solid catalyst was thoroughly washed with acetone for three times, dried, and then charged into the next run for reuse without further purification. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of catalysts The synthetic procedure for M-Salen-TBB-R is shown in Scheme 1 . Salen ligand was first obtained by reacting 4-(Diethylamino)salicylaldehyde and 3,3′-Diaminobenzidine, and its structure was determined by 1H NMR. Salen ligand acted as an ideal four-connected building block was then reacted with TBB and Co(OAc)2·4H2O by one-step in an autoclave still to construct the Co-Salen bridged ionic polymer networks Co-Salen-TBB. Co-Salen-TBB was further modified with Py, Mim, TEA, or TEOA to afford the resulting catalysts Co-Salen-TBB-R (R=Py, Mim, TEA, or TEOA). The solid catalysts are insoluble in almost all the commonly used solvents, like ethanol, acetonitrile, chloroform, THF, DMF, etc, and it is stable up to 200°C (Fig. S4 in SI). Thus, the catalyst synthesized herein is favorable for heterogeneous catalysis. The FT-IR spectrum of Co-Salen-TBB in Fig. 1 A shows the peaks at 1471, 1509 and 1612cm−1 assigned to stretching vibrations of the aromatic ring, and the peaks at 810, 750 and 648cm−1 corresponding to the bending vibrations of CH in the aromatic ring. The two bands at 1267 and 1147cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of CO and CN in Salen unit, respectively, whereas the peak at 544cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of CoO bond of the Salen moiety in the polymer framework. After the modification of Co-Salen-TBB with Py, the FT-IR spectrum of Co-Salen-TBB-Py exhibits a new absorption peak at 1569cm−1 assigned to stretching vibration of CN in pyridine. These vibrational signatures confirm the successful preparation of Co-Salen bridged ionic polymer network bearing pyridine functional groups. The pore structure and the surface area for these polymers were characterized by nitrogen sorption experiments at 77K. However, the result shows that Co-Salen-TBB-Py is almost nonporous with a BET surface area less than 2m2 g−1 (Fig. S5 in SI). The SEM image of Co-Salen-TBB-Py reveals an amorphous structure for it, which shows irregular micrometer sized particles. Element mapping (Fig. 1B) validates the homogeneous distribution of N, Br and Co on the surface of Co-Salen-TBB-Py. The percentage of Co atom in Co-Salen-TBB-Py determined by ICP-AES analysis is up to 4.71wt%, which is close to the theoretical value (4.99wt%) of fully metalation for Salen species. The above results demonstrate that the catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py displays unique cross-linked ionic polymer framework associated with high loading amount and homogeneous distribution of Co/Br− active centers. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further performed to investigate the oxidation states of the metal species. As shown in Fig. 1C, Co-Salen-TBB-Py shows peaks at 285, 399, 533, and 68eV for C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and Br 3d, respectively. The peak at 780eV is assigned for Co 2p. The peak positions for Co 2p1/2 at 796eV and for Co 2p3/2 at 781eV with a doublet peak energy separation of ca. 15.1eV (Fig. 1D) suggest that the Co ligated to the polymer framework corresponds to Co3+ [30–32]. The control catalysts Zn-Salen-TBB-Py and Al-Salen-TBB-Py were also characterized by XPS, and the spectra are shown in Fig. S6 in SI. The peak positions for Zn in Zn-Salen-TBB-Py and Al in Al-Salen-TBB-Py are matched well with those of the Zn(II) and Al(III) Salen compounds in the literatures [33,34]. EDS mapping images of Zn and Al for Zn-Salen-TBB-Py and Al-Salen-TBB-Py are also shown in SI as Fig. S7a and b, respectively. 3.2 Catalytic activity of Co-Salen-TBB-Py for cycloaddition reaction The prepared catalysts were first applied for the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO at 80°C with 0.5MPa CO2 pressure under solvent-cocatalyst-free conditions, and the results are illustrated in Table 1 . Co-Salen-TBB caused a solid-liquid heterogeneous catalysis system, and offered a moderate conversion of 77.2% with 100% selectivity (entry 2). However, the metal-free ionic polymer Salen-TBB merely showed a low conversion of 60.4% with 98.0% selectivity (entry 1). This comparison result clearly indicates that the Co metal center is play an important role for the high activity of the catalyst toward the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxide, and the enhancement of catalytic activity of Co-Salen-TBB should be attributed to the coordination action of Co metal centers and Br− anions [28,35]. It is known in the literatures [36–38] that the nitrogen N+ play an essential role as an organo-catalyst for the activation of CO2 in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates because it adopts a concave conformation suitable for the electrostatic stabilization of the Br− anion. Therefore, we investigated the effect of the N-containing IL cations towards the catalytic activity of catalysts. As shown in Table 1, entries 3–6, the cations had significant influence on activity. Co-Salen-TBB modified with Py or Mim exhibited pronounced catalytic activities, and Co-Salen-TBB-Py performed as the most active catalyst exhibiting the impressive conversion of 97.8% (entry 3). It is higher than that of Co-Salen-TBB-Mim which shows 85.1% conversion (entry 4). Electron-donating ability of N in the organic groups can affect the electron density on Br− [38], which may cause the variation of catalytic activities of catalysts Co-Salen-TBB-R. In order to prove this conclusion, catalysts Co-Salen-TBB and Co-Salen-TBB-Py were characterized by XPS. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , Co-Salen-TBB-Py presents a binding energy of Br 3d at 68.33eV, with a downshift of 0.29eV from the Br 3d of Co-Salen-TBB. This fact verifies that the excellent activity of Co-Salen-TBB-Py should be ascribed to the high electron density and leaving ability of Br− active sites that can promote the nucleophilic attack to epoxide. On the other hand, the less bulky triethylammonium cation might form a tighter ion pair with Br−, consequently decreasing its nucleophilicity and result in less viable [13,38]. As can be seen in entries 2 and 5, although Co-Salen-TBB-TEA was modified with TEA, but it presents a similar activity with 78.4% conversion and 97.8% selectivity to that of Co-Salen-TBB. Thus, the low catalytic activity of Co-Salen-TBB-TEA may be due to the poor nucleophilicity of Br− in the tight ion pair TEA+Br−. Interestingly, after the modification of Co-Salen-TBB with TEOA, the reaction efficiency was significantly enhanced. The obtained 93.7% conversion (entry 6) is much higher than that of Co-Salen-TBB-TEA. Hydrogen bonding has been reported to activate the epoxide. Hence, the increased activity of Co-Salen-TBB-TEOA possibly resulted from a strong chelating ability of OH through hydrogen bonding with the oxygen atom of the epoxide enabled the ring opening more easily [35,39,40]. It has been reported that Zn and Al metals could also act as the Lewis acidic center to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2. For comparison, M-Salen-TBB-Py with different metal centers were prepared and used as the catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO under similar reaction conditions as that in Table 1. The Zn-Salen-TBB-Py and Al-Salen-TBB-Py respectively showed 95.5% and 90.5% conversion. Al-Salen-TBB-Py presented lower activity than those of Zn-Salen-TBB-Py and Co-Salen-TBB-Py, which could be because Al3+ owns stronger Lewis acidity than Co3+ and Zn2+. The catalytic activity order Co>Zn>Al in our work is in good agreement with the previous studies [22,41]. Comprehensively, Co-Salen-TBB-Py was chosen as an efficient catalyst for further optimization of the reaction parameters. The influence of reaction temperature, catalyst amount, CO2 pressure, and reaction time were investigated, and the results are compiled in Table S1 in SI. A 99.8% conversion with 100% selectivity was observed under the even milder temperature of 60°C but with a slight higher CO2 pressure of 1MPa. To show the potential and general applicability of the metal-Salen-bearing ionic polymer networks, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides substituted with different functional groups over the catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py was investigated with 0.5MPa CO2 pressure at 80°C, and results are shown in Table 2 . It can be seen that, apart from cyclohexene oxide (CHO), four terminal epoxides can be successfully converted to the corresponding cyclic carbonates with very high conversions (>97%) and excellent selectivity (Table 2, entries 1–4). However, for the symmetrical internal epoxide CHO, a low conversion of 23.0% with 57.5% selectivity was obtained even with a long reaction time of 12h. The poor activity of CHO could be explained by the high force constant k of CO. In addition, the steric hindrance derived from the epoxide ring may limit the diffusion of epoxides thus impeding the nucleophilic attack to the carbon atom of the epoxide ring. Notably, over other Salen aluminum complexes and two-component catalyst system, it also could not give a high conversion of CHO [42–44]. The recyclability is considered to be a crucial criterion for heterogeneous catalysis. Then, we performed catalyst recycling studies for Co-Salen-TBB-Py in the fixation of CO2 with PO. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered simply by filtration, washed with acetone, dried at 60°C, and then directly reused for the next run. A five-run recycling performance was investigated, and the results in Fig. 3 show that Co-Salen-TBB-Py almost maintained its activity and selectivity throughout the five recycles. After the fifth run, the catalyst showed a 93.4% conversion of PO with 100% selectivity. The recovered catalyst was characterized by FT-IR, the spectra in Fig. 1A demonstrate that the recovered catalyst was in consistent well with that of the fresh one. Furthermore, the Co weigh percentage in the recovered Co-Salen-TBB-Py (4.66wt%) and CHN elemental contents (C 49.97wt%, H 5.30wt%, N 5.95wt%) in the recycled catalyst are detected to be similar to that of the fresh one. All the above observations reflect the excellent stability and structural durability of the present solid catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py. Obviously, not only our new catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py is advantageous to some existing halogen-based ILs, MOF and metal-Salen-based homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts in terms of activity and recyclability, but also the present catalysis systems is much more economic and environmental, i.e., needless to use any solvent and cocatalyst [17,45]. Furthermore, the catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py also exhibits a comparable catalytic performance to other bifunctional catalysts, which often require harsh reaction conditions to achieve high efficiency [26,46,47]. According to the previous reports, in the presence of a strong nucleophilic anion, Lewis acid sites can activate the epoxides for ring opening, and certain groups which can polarize the thermodynamically stable CO2 molecule to facilitate CO2 insertion can effectively catalyze the epoxide-CO2 cycloaddition [37,48–50]. Also, based on the experimental results over the bifunctional catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py, the synergistic effect between metal Co site, nucleophile Br−, and N+ cations is proposed to be the main reason for the enhanced catalytic activity under mild conditions. As illustrated in Scheme 2 , initially, epoxide is activated through coordination to Co centers. The Br− anion serves to attack the less-hindered carbon atom of epoxide at an appropriate angle, followed by the ring opening. Subsequently, the formed alkoxide species acts in turn as a nucleophile that attacks CO2 to form a metal catbonate anion, which is then converted into the corresponding cyclic carbonate through the ring-closure step, and the catalyst is regenerated. Certainly, the Py cations could stabilize the metal alkoxide bond through charge interactions. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have designed and synthesized a series of Co Salen-bearing ionic polymer networks modified with IL groups and used them as recyclable bifunctional catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides under mild and solvent-cocatalyst-free conditions. The optimum catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py exhibited the highest conversion of 97.8% with 100% selectivity at 0.5MPa, 80°C, 8h reaction conditions, and can be steadily reused for five times without significant decrease in activity and leaching of active Co species. It was found that the synergistic effect between functionalized active sites including metal center, nucleophile Br−, and organic cations afforded excellent performance of the catalyst Co-Salen-TBB-Py in cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions. Moreover, the catalyst supplies a unique highly cross-linked polymer framework structure associated with abundant and homogeneous distributed active centers, which provide high stiffness and stability of the catalyst. Therefore, the diversity and smart design strategy of the present catalyst might be a significant step towards the development of more rational heterogeneous catalysts with integrated and enhanced properties for clean-up CO2 fixation. coredata.dc:description: A series of bifunctional heterogeneous ionic polymer networks M-Salen-TBB-R were developed by reacting archetype of metal-salophen wtih 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(bromomethyl)benzene, followed by treatment with ionic liquid groups. Various techniques such as 1H NMR, TGA, CHN elemental analysis, SEM, FT-IR, XPS, and ICP-AES were used to characterize these catalysts. A number of attractive features like highly cross-linked polymer framework, abundant active sites of Lewis acid metal centers and nucleophile Br−, and various N-containing functional cations that endow the resultant catalysts with an expected talent for fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) under mild and solvent-cocatalyst-free conditions. The catalytic tests by comparison to various synthesized counterparts well demonstrate that this catalyst exhibit excellent activity and selectivity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, and the catalyst can be conveniently recovered and reused. The durable cross-linked network structure of catalyst and the cooperative effect between the metal center, Br−, and organic cations are responsible for the catalyst’s good performances in cycloaddition reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-salen-bridged ionic networks as efficient bifunctional solid catalysts for chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates
